thread.title: Hundreds march against Donald Trump state visit to Britain
thread.title_full: Hundreds march against Donald Trump state visit to Britain

author: Chris Slater
title: Hundreds march against Donald Trump state visit to Britain
text:
Hundreds march against Donald Trump state visit to Britain Protest in Albert Square was designed to 'send a message' to Prime Minister Theresa May Share Hundreds of protesters at a Stop Trump demonstration in Albert Square, central Manchester (Photo: Joel Goodman) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Protesters took to the streets of Manchester as a petition against a proposed state visit to the UK by Donald Trump was discussed in parliament. 
An estimated 300 people gathered in Albert Square to demand the invitation made to the new US president by Primer Minister Theresa May is withdrawn. 
After meeting in Piccadilly Gardens they marched through the streets to the gathering outside the town hall. 
They chanted "May and Trump have got to go" and held up placards deriding the businessman who became the 45th US President in January. Protesters at a Stop Trump demonstration in Albert Square, Manchester. (Photo: Joel Goodman) 
A number of speakers lambasted his policies on migrants and climate change, among other issues. 
It coincided with MPs debating the petition, signed by more than 1.8 million people, against any official visit to these shores by the controversial businessman turned politician. Read More 
It was part of a day of nationwide protests, with thousands gathering in Parliament Square in London. And it followed an event earlier in the day in Manchester support of refugees and asylum seekers. Protesters march to Albert Square, Manchester, in protest against Donald Trump. (Photo: Joel Goodman) 
Previous events in protest at Mr Trump in Manchester had seen between 5,000 and 10,000 turn out. And despite the much smaller numbers this time, organisers said they had made an important statement at the same time as the debate in Westminster. 
Steph Pike, 50, from new coalition group Stand Up to Trump said: "It was great, really lively. We wanted to send a message to coincide with the debate in parliament and certainly did that." Read More Thousands of women to take part in Reclaim the Night protest 
She said: "I think this is now the fifth protest since Donald Trump became President. 
"And time and time again the people of Manchester have shown that itâ€™s not just Donald Trump but his policies which people don't like and stand against." Watch: Previous Trump protest in Manchester city centre... Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
